posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Hi all, In the past day I‚Äôve come across many issues related to making a method that takes to long and overrunning the Command Scheduler‚Äôs loop.  When this only happens a few times, we don‚Äôt get any issues, but when it starts happening a lot, I believe we start getting the 'Watchdog Not Fed" message in driver station and the robot crashes.  I‚Äôve read up on what can cause this, and our code has no while() or even for() loops, no constantly updated data in SmartDashboard, and, as of now, no more print statements.  However, we are still getting the ‚ÄúCommand Scheduler Loop Overrun‚Äù message every so often.  I‚Äôve experimented, and I have noticed that resetting the odometry is an action that, by itself, exceeds the 0.02-second time limit and overruns the scheduler.  However, other actions are not so easy to pinpoint.  Sometimes the method that took too much time is a command.initialize() or command.execute() , but other times it is the buttons.run() call.  This is especially strange. Does anyone know how to fix this?  If it would be helpful in giving an answer, I will post my project. Thanks for the help!

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: You may take a look at setting up VisualVM on your robot project. This can give you a breakdown of exactly how long every function is taking to execute, and may help you narrow down where the problem(s) are: Profiling with VisualVM ‚Äî FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

link_counts.title: Profiling with VisualVM ‚Äî FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Alexander Hamilton
posts.cooked:
Paraduks:

buttons.run()

Take a look at this thread and this WPILib issue . It has a lot of good information regarding a possible root cause to this issue.

link_counts.title: CommandScheduler loop overruns -- one potential cause
Periodically calling CommandXboxController button functions causes CommandScheduler loop overruns ¬∑ Issue #5903 ¬∑ wpilibsuite/allwpilib ¬∑ GitHub

posts.name: Arshan
posts.cooked:
Paraduks:

but other times it is the buttons.run() call

We had a similar issue where buttons.run() was being polled too much  and was taking the longest out of the robot loop. From threads on Chief Delphi & trial and error, we isolated the problem down to being the way we fetch xbox controller states.

Rather than fetching states via something such as .getAsBoolean() or .getAsDouble() we created a HID object (see below; our robot container ) and instead fetch values from there. We essentially used the HID object (for both drive and operator control) for every single poll of the xbox controller (including dPad/POV) and it solved the problem on our side. (see example below)

Paraduks:

Sometimes the method that took too much time is a command.initialize() or command.execute()

It would be hard to pinpoint this problem since it may just be a specific problem with your code, so you would need to post your project.

Paraduks:

I‚Äôve read up on what can cause this

I believe this issue is caused by the fact that you are essentially setting up a new trigger event but rather than waiting for it to be fired you are directly calling its value therefore creating a new event/trigger every iteration of your robot which is bad practice altogether and as a result severely clogs up robot system resources.

I believe this issue is caused by the fact that you are essentially setting up a new trigger event but rather than waiting for it to be fired you are directly calling its value therefore creating a new event/trigger every iteration of your robot which is bad practice altogether and as a result severely clogs up robot system resources.

Proper explaination

Command Scheduler Loop Overrun Causes and Remedies Technical

Hope this helps

I‚Äôll clarify the issue here, as it seems to be causing some confusion. The issue is not polling the trigger value directly, or anything like that. It is calling the Trigger factories every loop . In addition to the GC pressure from so many objects, there‚Äôs also an issue with the implementation that causes loop overruns when these factories are called so many times. (This issue will be fixed for 2025.)

To illustrate the point:

Here, the problematic function is x ‚Äì there is no problem using getAsBoolean ! Caching the Trigger object, like the following, solves the issue:

Additionally, Trigger s are BooleanSupplier s, so there is only harm in this common use pattern:

This achieves the same result, without causing issues:

I hope I cleared up some confusion.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Thanks for the help everyone.  Yes, the issues I was facing did come from the issue in WPILib‚Äôs implementation of the controller interface.  I was able to fix it doing what @arshan and @Starlight220 recommend and, instead of getting the button trigger object by calling controller.a() , getting it by writing new Trigger(() -> controller.getHID().getA()) .  Hopefully WPILib fixes this for next year, the way I was doing it seems to be the obvious way of using their library, but, for now, this is a fine workaround.
